title: How to Gently Curl Your Hair

steps.headline: Apply a heat protection spray to your hair.
steps.description: If you have straight or fine hair, consider adding a mousse as well, from roots to ends. If you have thick or coarse hair, it might be a good idea to add a smoothing oil, from the middle of your hair down to the ends. The mousse or smoothing oil are optional. If you decide to use them, you should apply them in addition to the heat protection spray.

steps.headline: Blow dry your hair, if needed.
steps.description: If your hair feels damp after applying all those products, you'll need to dry it. Pull your hair taut and aim the hairdryer downward while drying it because it will prevent frizz. This will keep the strands nice and smooth.

steps.headline: Curl the first stands away from your face.
steps.description: Take a 1 to 2-inch (2.5 to 5-centimeter) wide vertical section of hair from next to your face. Wrap it around a 1¼-inch (3.2-centimeter) curling iron, going away from your face. Press down on the clamp, hold it for a few seconds, then unclamp it. Repeat this step for the other side of your face as well. Keep the temperature at 300°F (149°C) if you have fine to medium hair, and 340°F (172°C) if you have medium to coarse hair. A curling iron with a large barrel is important. Anything smaller, and you won't get those loose, gentle curls.

steps.headline: Curl the rest of your hair, altering the directions you curl in.
steps.description: Choose a side to start on, then work your way around the side of your head, towards the back. Alternate between curling the strands towards and away from your face. When you reach the back of your head, stop, then do the other side. Clip the finished strands out of the way as you go to keep you organized. Remove the clips when you are done. Curl shorter strands separately if you want extra volume.

steps.headline: Let your hair cool, then comb it with your fingers.
steps.description: This will help separate the curls and give you a more natural look. Do not use a brush or comb, otherwise your hair will frizz.

steps.headline: Finish off with a texturizing spray and hairspray, if desired.
steps.description: Lightly mist your hair with a texturizing spray, then scrunch it upwards as the spray dries. Set your style with a flexible hold hairspray, if needed. If your hair holds curls well or has a coarse texture, you may not need to do this.

steps.headline: Start with slightly damp hair.
steps.description: You can hop in the shower and get your hair wet, or you can mist your hair with water. If you decide to wash your hair, let it dry to the point where it is damp and no longer dripping. If your hair is not damp enough, it won't curl. If your hair is too wet, it will take too long to dry. You can find a water bottle for spritzing your hair at a beauty supply store or online. For best results, you will need to leave your hair curled for several hours - perhaps overnight - if you use this process. Alternatively, you could apply heat from a hair dryer or hooded dryer to speed up the process.

steps.headline: Slip a wide, fabric headband over your head.
steps.description: Choose a wide, fabric headband that is a few inches/centimeters wide. Slip it over your head, so that it rests right above your ears. Don't tuck it under your hair.

steps.headline: Split your hair into two equal-sized sections.
steps.description: Bring the left section over your left shoulder, and the right section over your right shoulder. Your hair should look as though you are about to make two braids. For smaller, tighter curls, you can split your hair into smaller sections. It will take more time for you to complete the process, but it will result in tighter curls.

steps.headline: Twist the left section onto a tight rope just behind your ear.
steps.description: Make sure that you are twisting it away from your face. Hold the rope at the end so that it doesn't unravel. If you have very long hair, you may need to position the rope right over your ear instead.

steps.headline: Wrap the rope around the headband, towards the back of your head.
steps.description: Pull the rope up, then under the headband. Give it another twist, and wrap it around the headband again. Keep wrapping the rope around the headband until you run out of hair. Twist your hair after each wrap. You want it to be as tight and snug as possible.

steps.headline: Repeat the process on the other side of your head.
steps.description: Twist the right section away from your face, then wrap it around the headband. Make sure that you are wrapping it upwards, just like you did for the left side. Keep the wraps nice and tight. Take a moment to tuck in any missed strands, especially if you have your hair cut into layers.

steps.headline: Let your hair dry completely.
steps.description: This is very important. If you take your hair out of the headband too soon, the curls will come undone. Most people will need to wait overnight, but some people may need to wait longer, especially if they have very thick or long hair.

steps.headline: Gently unwrap your hair and pull off the headband.
steps.description: Don't yank the headband off first, otherwise you risk undoing all your work. Instead, gently unwrap the ropes, starting from the back. Once you have your hair out of the headband, pull the headband off.

steps.headline: Separate your hair with your fingers.
steps.description: After taking your hair out of the headband, you'll likely be left with two big curls, one on each side of your head. Use your fingers to gently loosen those two big curls into smaller ones. Don't use a brush or comb, or your hair will frizz up.

steps.headline: Finish off with a texturizing spray and hairspray, if needed.
steps.description: Mist your hair with a texturizing spray. Cup your hand under your hair, then lift upwards towards your shoulder while the spray dries. This will help give you a little more volume. Finish off with a light misting of hairspray. If your hair is thick or holds curls well, you may not need to do either of these.

steps.headline: Choose a heat-less curling method to keep your hair healthy.
steps.description: Heat styling is fast, but it is harsh and can damage your hair overtime. Heat-less styling is much gentler. Depending on the style you want, you can get anything from loose, beachy waves to tight, springy curls.

steps.headline: Braid your hair while it's damp for natural, beachy waves.
steps.description: Get your hair wet, then part it down the middle. French braid or Dutch braid each side towards the nape of your neck, then finish off with a single braid. Let your hair dry completely, then undo the braid. Braids work well for creating waves in any hair texture. French braiding is when you add hair to the left and right strands before crossing them over the middle one. Dutch braiding is just like French braiding, except that you cross the left and right strands under the middle one.

steps.headline: Put damp hair into a sock bun overnight.
steps.description: Dampen your hair, then pull it up into a high ponytail. Cut the toes off of a sock, then roll it into a ring. Slide the ring onto your hair, then wrap your hair around the ring, starting from the ends. Let your hair dry, then remove the ring and undo the ponytail. Apply a styling mousse to your hair first for better hold.

steps.headline: Try pin curls for a vintage look.
steps.description: Dampen your hair first. Gather a 1-inch (2.5-centimeter) section of hair. Coil it into a spiral, then pin it in place at your scalp. Do this all over your hair, then let it dry. Remove the pin curls the next day, then comb them through with your fingers or a wide-toothed comb. Pin curls work best on straight or wavy hair. Cover your hair with a silk scarf and a shower cap to protect the curls. Use single prong clips or double prong clips to secure the spirals. These are small, metal hair clips that can be purchased at the average beauty supply store.

steps.headline: Twist your hair in baby wipes for springy curls.
steps.description: Twist a baby wipe into a rope, then wrap a section of hair around it, starting from the ends. Tie the baby wipe into a knot, then repeat the process all over your hair. Wait for the baby wipes to dry out, then remove them. Finger comb your hair to loosen and fluff the curls. Use thinner sections for tighter curls, and thicker sections for looser curls. You can also use a damp paper towel or napkin instead. You can wrap your hair all the way up to your scalp or a few inches/centimeters from it.

steps.headline: Twist and coil your hair for spiral curls.
steps.description: Apply a texturizing cream or mousse to a section of your hair. Twist the section away from your face into a rope, then coil it into a tight bun. Secure it with a bobby pin, then repeat the process all over your head. Let your hair dry, then remove the pins. Fluff the curls up with your fingers. The thinner sections you use, the tighter the curls will be. The thicker sections you use, the looser the curls will be. You can dampen your hair with water instead of using the cream, but you'll have to wait longer for it to dry. For best results, leave your hair twisted overnight so that the curls have time to set.
